CFC Kansas City, April 16/88
C.B&Q.RR.
Sir:
In continuation of the above operation
My operator G.F.G. further reports as follows: 
Saturday, April 14/88 - "I left the Agency at 8:30 a.m. and proceeded to the Union Depot. Upon my arrival at the depot I strolled through the yards and conversed with the employees and found that they apprehended no further trouble at present. The idea heretofore entertained that the Brotherhood was invincible is gradually wearing away and some think that the strikers will have to succumb. The new men on the switch engines are becoming more familiar with the yards and consequently there is not so much grumbling among the switchmen as when they first come out. Noticing a policeman
Completed

on a Hannibal engine I said to a switchman: "I see that the new men still have a body guard." His reply was: "Yes, I - unclear, they need them too! A policemen on a "2" engine is no figurehead. He is an actual necessity and will be for some time." 
Everything was quiet and orderly about the yards and I saw nor heard nothing that would lead me to suspect further trouble at present." 
My operator C.H.E. reports as follows: 
Thursday, April 12/88
"At 3 p.m. I left the Agency for the purpose of getting such information as W.H Courtney, a patrolman on Capt. McGraw's force was reports to have concurring the assault that was made upon two of the employees of the C.B.&Q R.R. in the Whittakers restaurant the morning of April 1st. I called upon Capt. McGraw but did not find him at his office. I saw his clerk and informed him of the business I was upon. He informed me the patrolman Courtney would not report until late in the evening.
Completed

but when he did he (the clerk) would learn all he could from him relation to what he might know of the assault. I then as per appointment proceeded to the Union Depot and called at the office of Mr. Fish. He not being in I waited until nearly 5 p.m. On his not returning I returned to the Agency and at 6:30 p.m. I again called at the office of Capt. McGraw. I saw the clerk. He informed me he had seen Officer Courtney and he had said he did not see the assault, but he believe he  could identify the man, as this was not in accordance with his assertions. I asked the clerk to request Capt. McGraw to speak to Courtney and endeavor to get all the information he could from him. I arranged to call again and see the Capt. I then returned to the Agency." 
My Operator G.F.G. further reports: 
Sunday, April 15th/88
"I left the Agency at 8:30 a.m. and proceeded to Union Depot. After arriving at the depot I walked through the yards and found every-
Completed

thing quiet and orderly. In conversing with the switchmen I find that they remember how the striking engineers acted during the switchmens' strike some time since. The switchmen claim that the switch engineers at that time instead of attending strictly to their own line of business also performed the duties of the switchmen. Many railroad men think the firm stand taken by the "Q" road in the present contest will be a great help towards preventing railroad strikes in the future. They also think that had the company yielded to the demands of the strikers trouble would be likely to occur in other departments during the summer. There is a growing belief that the strikers will, before a great while, come back and ask to be re-instated in their former positions and agree to the terms and conditions that the company has dictated." 
Yours respectfully,
Pinkertons Natl. Detective Agency
W.A. Pinkerton
Genl Supt. W.D.
Completed

The switchmen claim that the switch engineers at that time instead of attending strictly to their own line of business also performed the duties of the switchmen. Many railroad men think the firm stand taken by the "2" road in the present contest will be a great help towards preventing railroad strikes in the future. They also think that had the company yielded to the demands of the strikers trouble would be likely to occur in other departments during the summer. There is a growing belief that the strikers will, before a great while, come back and ask to be re-instated in their former positions and agree to the terms and conditions that the company has dictated." 
Yours respectfully,
Pinkerton's Nat'l Detective Agency
W.A. Pinkerton
Genl Supt. W.D.
Completed

Kansas City, April 17/88
C.B.&Q. R.R. C.F.C.
Sir: 
In continuation of the above operation
My operative C.F.C further reports as follows: 
Monday, April 16th/88- 
"I left the Agency at 8:30 a.m. and proceeded to the Union Depot for the purpose of gathering such facts as would be of interest to the company. Upon my arrival I found everything quiet about the yards. many with whom I conversed think that if labor organizations were as united and as willing to pull together corporations are that they would have better chances of success. They also think that until they can get legislation favorable to the laboring classes they will be obliged to submit to the demands of the corporations. I learned no new feature concerning the
Completed

strike. There is very little talk about it and no excitement whatever. I mixed with the railroad men and remained about the different rendezvous and noticed that there was an evident uneasy feeling amongst them. They have very little to say and all are in hopes of something may happen to give them a chance to go back to work and return in a way that won't be humiliating. They don't seem to know how they stand. Dissections are breeding They are looking for some turn that will be advantageous to them."
Yours respectfully,
Pinkerton's Nat'l Detection Agency
W.A. Pinkerton
Gen'l Supt W.D.
Completed

Kansas City, April 18/88
C.B.&Q. R.R.  C.F.C.
Sir: 
In continuation of the above operation
My Operative C.F.C. further reports as follows: 
Tuesday, April 17th/88
"I left the Agency at 8:30 a.m- Upon my arrival at the depot I found it quiet about the yards, although there had been some damage done during the night by the strikes or their sympathizers. The switchmen and other employees are reticent about the affair and don't seem to want to talk much about it. They declare boys are doing the mischief and the blame is thrown on them. In conversation with one of the strikers he said: "The newspapers made a big thing out of what occurred and anything that happens to cause an accident which
Completed

is the result of carelessness. The railroad company claim it is done to wreck. There's no use talking, the railroad company had won this time and it's foolish to think otherwise. We are beat, and its through bad management on the part of Arthur and Stevens. The next time we'll show more strength." 
Muller was very busy to-day but I could not learn what it was about. At 7 p.m. I discontinued." 
Yours respectfully
Pinkerton's Nat'l Detection Agency
W.A. Pinkerton
Gen'l Supt. W.D.
Completed

Kansas City April 19/88
C.B. & 2. R.R.  C.F.C. 
Sir: 
In continuation of the above operation
My Operative C.F.C. further reports as follows: 
Wednesday, April 18/88: 
"I left the Agency at 8:30 a.m. Upon my arrival at the depot I found people in groups discussing the features of the switchmans "lay off." I heard nothing of importance to the company. After the strike was settled and the men resumed work the crowd dispersed and everything was comparatively quiet during the afternoon. I hear an occasional allusion to the "scabs." The men were attending to their work with regularity and everything was orderly and quiet at 6 o'clock p.m. when I returned to the Agency. Yours respectfully,
Pinkerton's Nat'l Detective Agency
W.A. Pinkerton
Genl Supt W.D.
Completed

Kansas City, April 20th/88
C.B.&Q.R.R.  C.F.C.
Sir: 
In continuation of the above operation
My Operative C.F.C. further reports as follows: 
Thursday, April 19/88
"I left the Agency at 8:30 a.m. Upon my arrival at the depot I found everything in quietness. In talking with a striking engineer to-day he stated that although the company had money and law on its side, it cannot have everything its own way. He said that he did not countenance violence, but still if a little were perpetuated occasionally it was not so bad, so long as it did not injure any innocent person, but he did not consider "scabs" innocent people. I was also talking with a switchman  who said that they were cautioned about talking too
Completed

2.
much with outsiders. he stated during the conversation that something might occur when the people least expected it. He also said that he talked too much sometimes when he had taken a few "beers." I think that there is a greater liability of trouble during the first week after pay day. Everything quiet at 6 p.m. when I left that vicinity and returned to the Agency." 
Yours respectfully,
Pinkerton's Nat'l Detective Agency
W.A. Pinkerton
Genl. Supt. W.D.
Completed

Kansas City, April 21/88
C.B.&Q.R.R. T.D
Sir:
In continuation of the above operation 
My Operative T.D. reports as follows:
Friday, April 20/88.
"I left the Agency at 2 p.m. and went to the Union Depot. On my arrival at the depot I heard three men talking about the strike, which proved to be two engineers and a fireman. They said they had a notion to give it up, yet the Brotherhood was too strong to weaken so soon. I was talking with a fireman who said the company would go up before a month the way they are working now, and he hoped they would. I discontinued at 9 p.m. and returned to the Agency." Yours respectfully,
Pinkerton's Nat'l. Detection Agency 
W.A.Pinkerton
Genl. Supt. COD.
Completed

W A H
Kansas City, May 8/88
H.B. Ston, Esq.
Genl. Mngr. C.B.&Q R.R.. Chicago, Ill.
Sir:
My Operative W.A.H. further reports as follows:
Monday. May 7th/88.
"Leaving the Agency at 8 a.m. I proceeded to the vicinity of the Union Depot. Shortly after I met Bill Ware?, my roommate while in St. Joseph. He said, in talking of the strike, that it would be soon settled so far as the engineers and fireman were concerned, but added: "But look out for the switchmen"! I asked him what he meant. He did not reply further than to say: "Well, they'll raise things? yet! We remained together some time and joined several groups, but any mention as to what further action was intended was avoided, or, at least, was not broached. At 1046 Union Avenue there was
Completed

some little excitement in the way of a rumor to the effect that the Santa Fe ws giving work to engineers and firemen and one party said if the order went to the Brotherhoodo it would cause trouble, as should they select them there would be a chance only for friends of the officers. A man named Mack said: "There's nothing in it and there's no use in getting in a sweat about it." 
During the evening all was quiet about the depot and Union Avenue. very few strikers being around. I discontinued at 9 p.m."
Yours respectfully, 
Pinkerton's Nat'l. Detection Agency.
W.A. Pinkerton.
Gen'l Supt. W.D.
Completed

E.T.M.
Chicago May 1st 1888
H.B. Stone
Genl. Manager of the C.3 20 City
Dear Sir.
Following you will please find report of my operative "E.T.K."
Wednesday, Apr 11/88
To-day in Mendota
This morning Opt went went to the Yard at 7:30 Am and remained until 12 M. and from 1 Pm to 6:45 when he discontinued and nothing happened of importance during this time.
Thursday Apr 12th
Everything passed off quietly untill 3:10 Pm today when Opt. says: "Frederick Blackburn of Engine #136 was comming to his work he was accosted by a party of striking switchman and others all strikers who wanted him to go up to their meeting which was going on: he refused and they assulted him. Opt arrested them and the striking engineer was fined $11.50. Another charge of carrying concealed weapons was preffered against the fireman and a change of venue was taken by the firemans
Completed

2
counsel" The Mayor of the town to another Justice where he was fined $15.00 and his fine was paid by the Brotherhood Engineers. Opt says a number of them come up to the depot in the afternoon and he turned them away 5 or 6 of them went to Aurora and the Opt there was notified and nothing else happening Opt. discontinued. 
Friday April 13th 1888
Everything passed of quietly there today Opt says untill 3:30 Pm when a train came in from the west with a lot of striking engineers on board named Edward Battles, Edward Kelley, Smith and Fred Dewey they come out on the platform as 3 three more striking engineers belonging there come up named White, . The president Pierce and Vansllyke. and as Opt. had ordered of previous times he took the largest Vanslyke by the arm and shoved him along at this he rebelled but the second time Opt shoved him he went. The witness to this affair were the Hotel proprieter I.W. Hutchinson, Engineer Fuller, and both depot masters. Opt was arrested at 5:30 Pm by the Marshall of the town and taken before a justice of the Piece and placed under $100.00 bail untill the next day at noon." The Agt. Mr Heury becoming his surety. The warrent was sworn out by Pierce. The men on the
Completed

3
train went on to Aurora and he sent word to my Opt. there to watch for them: Everything is quiet and Opt. discontinued. 
Saturday Apr 14/88
Nothing of importance occurred on the arrival of the train at 11::55 am. The (6) striking engineers got off and departed from the grounds. Opt. trial come up at 1 Pm before Justice Cromwell? and Opt. atty "The Mayor" took a change of venue to Justice Gray where he secured a continuence untill Thursday Apr 19/88 at 12 M. There was about 30 of the strikers present (3) three of whom were brought from Aurora for witnesses. After the adjournment 15 of the strikers come over to the depot where a train was but as soon as it pulled out Opt. ordered them off the companys grounds and they went Opt. is held in $200.00 bail untill the 19th. Among the most noticeable men in court was a man named Clark. There is a number of strikers in town today but Opt could not find out for what purpose and at 9:15 Pm he discontinued. 
Sunday Apr 15th/88
Opt says last night at 11:30 Pm a large stone was thrown into Eng #20 window and struck the Engineer on the head and it happened about  a quarter of
Completed

4
a mile from where the guards were stationed. Nothing of importance happened today everything quiet and Opt discontinued
Monday Apr 16th/88
Today in Aurora everything passed of quietly and in yesterdays report Opt forgot to report about a Brakeman was there and employed on the "2" road named Shaffer. Yesterday morning he and Opt "13" while on their way to the Barber Shop this man tried to obstruct their way and after returning they found him sitting at the depot when asked his business he replied "he had none."  he was then ordered away the second time he said it was a shame people could not stand around the depot. Opt told him to mind his business and his situation when he said "dam the situation and he did not care whether the company knew it or not. Opt then notified Agt. Henry who in time unclear Mr Alexander at Aurora. Opt says there was another brakeman here named Hobrook on the Clinton and Fulton branch who tried to get an engineer to go up to the Brotherhood [[unclear] with hm. Opt. says he must delay his reports 2 hours as he has lately heard some things spoken that he supposed
Completed

5
was strictly private and went to shadow this man". The night operator" for the C. 3&2 RR name of Patrick Warren and saw him visiting the Headquarters of the Strikers. He leaves the office at 8 Am and can be seen in the midst of them every day and the night policeman told Opt at 3:45" Am that a proof of his dispatches could be seen with the strikers: everything was quiet to-day and Opt discontinued 
Wednesday Apr 18th/88
To day everything passed off quietly nothing of importance happening all day Opt says his trial comes of tomorrow at 1 PM and at 9:15 he discontinued 
Yours Respectfully,
Pinkerton National Det Agency
by Wm A Pinkerton 
Genl. Supt of West. Agency
Completed

Chicago Mar 23"1888
H.B. Stone Esq
C.B. & Q RR City
Dear Sir
Below please find report of operative Will.
March 18" 1888
Today in Creston? left hotel at 6:30 am went to engineers headquarters left there at 12 Noon as instructed by M.M. Eckerson? and went to Millers Hotel. unclear three Brotherhood were there, one said he intended to go back to work if strike was not settled by Saturday. Second man said he would do the same, the third one made threats that if first two did, there would be trouble. Heard nothing of any importance up to 9 P.M. when I discontinued
March 21" 1888
Left the hotel at Creseton today at 6:30 am went to engineers headquarters. There were fifteen new engineers arrived in the course of the day, some of them left their revolvers in their bunks and had them stolen. Reported to Supt Dugan and received instructions from him to learn if possible the names of some of the Non-Union were in the city. Was with
Completed

unclear Dugan till a lateunlcear. Nothing of special importance occurred. 
Report of Opr G.D.C. Tuesday March 20/88  Today in Galesburg each? Wardens & unclear in hotel office, played cards with them till about 9.00, unclear executes later was instructed by J.C. McGuire to report to unclear Howard anything that occurred. Unlcear week to the White Elephant saloon
Completed

3.
them. Opr took these two men to dinner with him. At 2 P.M. Wanders? left saying he had a unclear to go to the Jastice? Coach and leave the trial. Met Hintau the switchman went to Union Hotel ban with him where he met unlcear who told him that unclear was fined twenty five dollars & costs. The mayor was on hand and spoke against the strikers and nothing was done with the scab. Opr then went to Santa Fe depot unclear house and several other places unclear said the barber who induced the two firemen to go back to work would be boycotted and that they Brotherhood had committees on the Depot trying to get the new Engineers to go back and were offering them every inducement. A striker then came in and told Wardeau that there was a man stopping on the unclear who would have to be watched
Completed

4
the object being to help the engineer on the L. to win the strike providing they would help them in return. The switchman also wants to draw on the funds of the Brod of Engineers. If they consolidate they will call the engineers on the Lake ? out in order to get the scab on Non-Union switchmen discharged who are now employed by the ? also if the switchmen & engineers agree the switchmen's union will order a strike on the ? Wayne Road if an agreement can be arrived on the switchmen will not strike, the result of the meeting will be made known tonight. Opr. also heard that a yardmaster and four new struck in the ? N-Western year, the object being, Yardmaster wanted $175.00 for month. Opr returned to ? 3:00pm Opr F.M. P. reports under date ? Today the men in my detail all reported to the station at 6:30pm took the 5:40 train to Western Ave Crossing, remained on duty all night, escorted four trains of stock to stockyards. Nothing of an unusual occurrence during the night. 
March 21
Same Opr reports reposts that as detailed he and his man, guarded Western Avenue Crossing as on the previous night. The only incident of ? was the
Completed

5
derailment of a switch engine about 10 o'clock by running through a broken switch just east of Western Ave. Everything was righted by 11 o'clock. Nothing also special during the night. Same Opr reports under date "Mar 22" 1888 A wreck was reported at Hawthorne about 10:30pm. 1st #85 collided with a switch engine. Could not learn anything authentic regarding it, but do know that the switchman in charge, a man ? McLaughlin will ? watching may closely. He is very bitter against the engineer and is making threats against the new men. Nothing serious occurred during the night.
Opr J.A.D. under date of "March 18" says the week to Grand Crossing to meet ten engineers in charge of Opr Tobias of New York coming are the 9:30pm time of ? took them to the Riggs House and remained there till 12 noon Monday
Under date of March 20 Opr. G.W.M. says that on 6:10am with a detail of 28 men went to the ? Crossing and the yards of ? remained there and gave men their ? and returned to Agency on 6:40pm Nothing special to report
Opr J.H. says under date of Mar 20 1888 Since reporting yesterday from Galesburg
Completed

all has been quiet with the exception of the shouting of the man Phillips, his assailant were fined $25.00 and costs.
Report of Opr W.J.W. "March 21" 1888
Today in Chicago was under instructions from Supt. Robertson to meet Mrs Edge? and daughter on train No 5 L I & M.S.R. When train at 11:05 took Mrs E & daughter to hotel and made them comfortable for the night. Promised to see them safely off on the O.B. & L. train.
March 22 1888
Today in charge Opr W.J.W. left Agency at 10:30am went to Banks Hotel meet Mrs Edge? & daughter took them to Union Depot and left them in charge of Passenger Agent ? Jake Wilson with instructions to see that they got away on noon train saw that they were well provided for had their baggage brought over from ? Depot to O.B. & L and gave Mrs E pass for herself and daughter 'paid' him ? fare she 'paid' from the east and took receipt for same also paid hotel bill and baggage transfer charges did everything possible to make this comfortable.
Opr G.W.M. under date of Mar 21 reports, At 6:10am. left Chicago Agency with detail of 28 men went to ? Crossing and
Completed

2
? years detailed two men for duty at crossing and eighth for duty are engines going to stock yards Lumber destruct & St. Paul yard four for engines in Ewing Oh and Wabash & ? yards. two for Dubuque Engines from ? Crossing to Ill A Depot and return to 12? Round House. Remaining twelve men were posted along the yard from Canal to Blue to Blue Island Ave. and at Wood St. 
Nothing of any note occurred up to the change of watch. Men returned to Agency on 7:00pm-
Opr G.W. ? date of Mar 20 reports - 
In Aurora today, knocked about among the saloons and other places where the strikers congregate, whenever there was a rumor of any kind Opr investigated it but found everything quiet. Nothing special to report.
Opr F.W. at Aurora ILl makes the following report under date of Mar 20. Looked over all the descriptions of E & R R men. Tried to find T. Farrell the man just left off with a fine. The R men are keeping very quiet but are watching every new man, they may make trouble for the skabs if they should come down town. Y. W. Rhodes ordered Opr F.W. & R. G. to carry out same instructions he gave them.
Opr T.W. V. under date of March 21 says
Completed

8
Today in Clinton everything was very quiet no disturbance of any kind W.F. ? reposted to Opr and was sworn in and assigned to duty. Opr delivered salaries to men at Fulton and found everything quiet there, though the crowd ? watching as hey seem to feel better towards the Company this is also the state of affairs at Mendola - Opr W.H. N. writes from Overton under date of March 20 1888.
Left Hotel today at 6:30 went to engineer headquarters and remained there til 11:00 o'clock. Freight Agent Murray ? gave Opr pointer on suspicious looking ?. Shadowed him till a late hour but could see nothing suspicious in the actions -
Opr W.L. in Chicago Mar 21 reports- Went to Union Depot at 8A.M. found everything quiet there went to 16th St. Had same talk with an employee of the P.F.W. Ry. learned from him that the switchmen had each decided what action they would take from 16th went to Grand Pacific Hotel where it was understood a meeting was to be held, then went to 55th St. learned ? name of the switchman that they had ? decided to strike. Returning to the Grand Pacific Hotel Opr learned from a Wm Smith employed in R. House
Completed

9
and when has a brother who is an engineer that the boys would have to give in, but that there was same talk about calling out the R Ry in the ? of same of the dissatisfied engineers ? are determined to win. Understood that meetings were being held at Elgin Armory and other points by the brotherhood of engineers and that there was a good deal of dissatisfaction ? the men. 
Yours Respectfully
Pinkertons Nat Det Agency
by Wm A Pinkerton
Gen Supt. West Div.
Completed
Chicago Apl 10" 1888  Paul Montau Esq Dear Sir For your information please read the enclosed report J.C. McGuire
Completed

Chicago April 10" 1888 H.B. Stone Esq Gen Manager C.B. & Q R.R. City  Dear Sir Following please fine report of F.S.  Monday April 9" 1888 Today in Ottawa Opr says that at 9.30 last night as officer Adolple Bueben? was patrolling his beat at the east end of the yard, he states that there was a mob of men between the Burlington and Roen Island tracks who commenced to thrown stones at him so rapidly that he could not get out of the way without getting hurt so he drew his revolver and fired in the direction of the mob which attracted the attention of Opr as well as ll of his men, and in about three minutes time ten of them were on hand ready for an attach. They could not see the unclear in the dark as they bad withdrawn some distance. Considerable noise could be heard followed by shots apparently fired from unclear not far away from where Opr stood. Opr and men waited for the
Completed

expected attack but the mob dispensed and all remained quiet during the night. Opr telegraphed facts to Mr. Vallius an Orestou and asked for help as he fully anticipated trouble. At 11.30 P.M. Mr. Vallius asked by telegraph "How does it look now" Opr ansered "Everything is quiet, we are all here and will protect ourselves" At 12.40 A.M. a telegram from Mr. Vallius said "Use caution but stand firm will be there on next train" with six men. At 5 A.M. Mr. Vallius came and everything was quiet he sent the men back to Orestou remaining here himself. None of our men were hurt. Opr says if any person else was injured be knows nothing of it. Your Respectfully Pinkerton Nat Det Agency by Wm A. Pinkerton Gen Supt West Div
Completed

Chicago May 5th/88 Mr H.B. Stone Genl. Manager C,B, &Q R.R. City Dear Sir Following please find reports of my Opr. "T.N.V"  Wednesday Apr 11th/88 Today in Burlington Opr reports everything quiet during the night and day. It was pay day today and the Brotherhood men claimed that the new men would be all drunk and there would be lots of trouble and Opr. took the necessary precautions to prevent it. Opr then went uptown and become acquainted with the Mayor and Chief of Police and found the Mayor George Duncan to be a good friend of the Pinkerton unclear and of the C.B. & Q R.R. Co and he will heartly render any assistance necessary. Thursday Apr 12/88 Opr reports everything quiet there today and nothing of importance occurring during his watch so he proceeded to Criston to see how matters stood and assist if possible in
Completed

in any trouble that may arise as he had heard there was stones thrown, windows broke and a switchman was assaulted on the street: he arrived at Creston at 2.25 PM. Opr being unknown traveled among the strikers all "Knights" and Brotherhood men and found the feeling very bitter towards the company and thinks there will be trouble if the guards are drawn away as was proposed by Supt Brown. Opr. expects there will be trouble there when the new men get paid and nothing else of importance occuring he discontinued.
Friday Apr 13th/88 Today Opr. reports everything was quiet in Creston untill 7.40 PM at which time 4 of the new men were assulted and one of the party unclear finely being knocked down fired 2 shots at the strikers but without any effect. Opr says he knows the parties and will try to have them prosecuted tomorrow. They too the revolvers away from the man that did the shooting and followed another to the Hotel and knocked him down with a revolver. Yours Respectfully Pinkertons National Det Agency by Wm. A. Pinkerton Genl. Supt of West Div
Completed

Chicago May 8" 1888 H.B. Stone Esq Gen Manager C.B. & Q R.R. City Dear Sir Following please find report of Opr. E.S.G. Friday May 4" 1888 Today at 10 A.M. Opr received the following instructions from Gen Supt R.A. Pinkerton and Asst Supt J.C. McGuire, "go to Grand Pacific Hotel and endeavor to obtain a room on the fist floor and as near as possible to the one occupied by S.E. Hoge chairman of the grievance committee of the striking engineers of the C.B. & Q. RR Co. His room being No 34 and there to form the acquaintance of the Chambermaid who attends to his room for the purpose of having her get from his room any letters that way be lure during his absence from the room and allow us to see them and get a copy of such of items as unclear related to the new engineers that are seen at work on the road. Also to ascertain when this girl can get out and unclear unclear
Completed

unclear a shadow way be put upon her to leave unclear tablets? Opr after changing his clothing settled his bill where he had been stopping and taking a cab drive to R.R. depot and after a short stop there took another cab to the Grand Pacific Hotel arriving there at 2.30 PM and registered under the name Samuel Gordon, Boston Mass and upon applying for a room in the desired location Opr was assigned to room No 31 which is directly opposite to room No 34 which is directly opposite to that of S.E. Hoge that being the only room on the floor and that particular side of the house that was vacant.The room N0 36 next to Hoge's is occupied and No 32 on the other side of his is under going repairs. Opr saw four different girls on work on that floor all apparently Irish they had evidently attended to all of the rooms and were on work in the hall and parlor. Opr saw a middle aged Irish woman come out of No 30. She was of stock build and red face apparently one of the chamber maids of the rooms at this floor. Opr remained in his room the greater portion of the afternoon but received one visit and that from one of the firls who came in with towels. A different one from those already referred to. At 6.30 PM Opr went to supper
Completed

supper and returned to his room at 7.30 PM. unclear was a light in Hoge's room for a few minutes about 8 O'Clock and then it was dark the rest of the evening up till 10 O'clock. There is considerable walking up and down the hall by the guests and a hall boy is stationed in a chair in front of the passage to the elevator which is but a few steps from Opr's room. Hoge's room has a connection with room No 32 and Opr thinks unclear with 36 but is not quite sure as to that. Saturday May 5" 88 Today Opr reported to Supt McGuire at 8 AM and there returned to the hotel. The chambermaid had just commenced to woke up the room, there was also a girl in Hoge's room and two other girls at work in the room in the same hall. Opr spoke to the girl in his room, just passing the time of day and leaving some change made in the bed covering. She was not at all backward and rather inclined to be talkative being a young Irish girl. She did but little in Oprs room as it is rather small and no bath attached and therefore the girl did not remain long. Opr remained in the room all of the forenoon and could hear a number of different people going into Hoge's room, majority of them giving a light tap on the door and others going in
Completed

without knocking. Opr had dinner at PM and reported to Asst Supt McG at 3 PM and then returned to the hotel. Dear Sir Following please find report of John Maher Sgt in Charge at Mendola Ills from the 17th of July until and including July 25th. Officer Reports that on July 17th Everything passed off all quiet and nothing of importance to report. - they go on duty at 6.30 p,m. and leave off at 6.30 a.m.
July 18th 1888 Officer further Reports that everything was as usual same as on yesterday excepting that a conductor told Sgt to look out for a man wearing a star which read City Marshall and represented himself as an employee for the purpose of riding free. Sgt traced him for a while and he went to the Telegraph Office where he acted very important and saucy, not being able to influence the Operator. Sgt saw he was a fraud and that he had neither letter or badge of any kind. Officer demanded these and told him to leave soon as possible which he did.

Chicago July 30th 1888 H.B. Stone Esq Genl Mgr. C.B. & Q R.R. city
Dear Sir Following you will please find report of Opr J.M. 
Saturday July 28th 1888 Today in Mendota Opr reports that the Passenger Train No 3 was stoned last night two miles east of here, by a party of six drunken scandinavians. Three of the party live in Meriden and other here. They were all arrested and Opr had a party on guard at the jail which is a poor shed. The Conductor on arriving here, pointed out to Opr three broken lights. One was in a sleeper and a lady narrowly escaped being hurt. They got the stone that had missed her and realising that something should be done, they at once, after some urgin, got a switch engine and a party with officer {{Bial?]] of Mendota, who is a good man, started back and got one man about a mile out they stopped and arrested him, they searched him and found a stone and a bottle of whiskey in his
Completed

2. 
pockets. He ran, but one shot made him halt. Opr had him guarded and they proceeded on their way. They dropped twp of the party about half a mile further, and a man who was hiding in the grass ran back into their arms, but Opr did not know this at the time and proceeded on his way. They others laid low & Opr & his party missed them so they came back and pumped their prisoner as to the others were and got the names of the whole six. They again took the switchengine and went back to Meridan. They woke up on family and found where the three men they were after lived, so they went to the house and the man there not knowing what the Opr wanted pointed out to him the three men. Two of them had whiskey flasks in their coats. Opr brought them back and pumped one of them and he said that one sweede said "Boys, let us give it to the scabs." and as the stones were handy they did, the same man making the remark. "they would blame us for it." As they still had one man to get, Opr & Beil went and got him. This man, the others claimed had a revolver. The men sulked on the way walking to Meridan. Three of them are sections hands. Opr. has not in
Completed
vestigated matters yet. Your Respectfully Pinkerton Nat'l Det. Agency By W.A. Pinkerton Genl. Supt W. Div

Chicago July 31st 1888
H.B. Stone Esq
Genl. Mgr. C.B.&Q R.R 
City
Dear Sir: Following you will please find report of Opr. J.M. Sunday July 31st 1888. Today in Mendota Opr. reports that all is quiet now. The six men whom they arrested Saturday night and against whom Opr. had evidence of guilt, were released by Mr. Henry, the Company's agent here to day. Opr and Officer Biel outlined to him this morning what they knew of the matter. The men arrested were all in the Company's employ as section hands, and it is now known that they all done a share of the stone throwing. Mr. Henry sent for the road master at Aurora, and it may be that they did not want to public to know that their own men did it; letting them go is not favorably commented upon here, even by his own men & officer Biel who feels same. Yours Respectfully Pinkerton's Nat'l Det. Agency By W.A. Pinkerton Genl. Supt. W. Div R

Dear Sir, Following please find report of D.D.C. dated at Chicago Aug 31st 1888 (Friday)
Operative reports that at 8 o clock he went to Noonan Bros. and there found a few of the boys and found that Murphy was right last night when he told Opr that there was noting new in the meeting yesterday! and in fact there is nothing new yet. The Political Club is booming and as soon as they are organized, they intend to come out as an Independent Club and show their strength and in that way they think they will attract the attention of Office Seekers and get them to pledge themselves to the boys. Aside from this there is nothing new in regard to the strike. They don't know when there will be a change but they are ready for one of most any kind! Opr stayed at Noonan Bros a short time and went to dinner and then went back there again! and remained there until 8 o'clock but learned nothing more. 
Yours Truly Pinkerton National Detective Agcy per W.A. Pinkerton Genl Supt West Div.
Completed

Chicago Sept 6th 1888
H.B. Stone Esq.
General Manager C.B.&Q. R.R. Chicago
Dear Sir:
Following find report of Opr. D.D.C. dated at Chicagoo: Sept 5th 1888:
Operative reports that at 8 oclock A.M. he went to the Union Depot and there met Martin Flaherty: who said there was a good deal of dissatisfaction among the men on account of the Pay and that he was going over to see Moynigan (and by the way Opr says that that there is ill felling between Moynigan and Flaherty) Opr thought he would accompnay Flaherty and see what he could learn, therefore Opr accompanied Flaherty - and together they went to the vicinity of McCoys Hotel and met Cook and O'Brein! but Monigan was not there Mr. unclear expected him at any time: so Opr stayed around there: and there went away learning word that they would call again. Flaherty and Cook in the meantime went to see Pat McGrath clerk of the Superior Court who wants the Office again: they wanted to get some money out of him but he is going to see them again and if he thinks the Independent Club can be won over for him, he will put up some money. Flaherty told McGrath that they were under heavy expense one of these items was 10.00 per week for a Room at McCoys.
Completed

Hotel and thought if McGrath could start in by paying this Rent for them then it would show the members that he meant business and would help Greatly to win the boys Over!
Mr. McGrath though this was all very well and would see them tomorrow or next fday.
After leaving McGrath they went back to see Mr. Monigan it was now about 2 oclock and they found him shortly: and he and Flaherty had some words hastily: (It seems that Monigan blames Flaherty for Jennings and Artkin abusing Connors the other day Monigan said if any men talked to him as Jennings talked to Connors he would have satisfaction if he lost his life for it- They: Flaherty and Monigan finally partd, seemingly good friends but Opr thinks each is a little jealous of the other. After leaving Monigan They went to the McCoy Hotel and there met a few of the boys but nothing new was learned. Opr stayed around there until 5 oclock and started for Noonan Bros: but did not get there as he met Tom Murphy who was at the meeting and said there was nothing new. Only the Darn fools was a little more quiet today than they had been for a few days past. So Opr got home about 6 p.m. without going to Noonan Bros.
Your Truly
Pinkerton Nat. Det. Agcy
Per W.A. Pinkerton Genl Supt
West Div
Completed

Chicago 4-14th 1888
Report of Information
By David Ramage
Information gained from one of the new Switchmen to the effect that a bomb was to be placed in the Round house of the C.B. & Q. R.R. Co. A boy was gave his name as Mullen a son of one of the Striking Engineers told the Switch man that he heard his father say that they were going to fix the Scabs some of those nights the Switch man asked him what was going to be done the boy said put a boomb into the Round house and kill all the Scabs if they could the Boy is around the Round house Every night about supper time
I will get the Switch man's name today (15th) if possible
Signed
David M. Ramage. Deputy Sheriff
Completed

C.B.&Q RR City
Dear Sir
Following please find report of Opr M.J.
March 28" 1888
Today in Chicago
Opr went to the C&E.I. yards with switchman who has charge of Engine No 29. Opr spoke to him and was recognized as a C.B.&Q. Switchman. Opr said he had heard that the "Q" was bringing a train to the C&E I and asked him what he would do when it arrived, switchman said that both he and Engineer would be sick. Opr went to Halsted St between 14th & 15th and each a switchman unclear Monroe. In course of conversation this switchman requested Opr to see Frank Wells one of the committee of the Switchman's union. Opr made an appointment with this committee man and met him in a saloon corner of 14th and Halsted St. Another switchman named Patrick unclear was with him. They explained to Opr. that in case the C.B.&Q. transfer was received a switchman was to go (when detailed) from other roads to his engineer and say I am going to the "Q" and if he declines to go report
Completed

2
the circumstance to yard master and should be take another engine and couple it onto the train, you tell that Engineer the same thing, and if he refuses notify the yard master, and there if they take a man who has not been in the employ as a yard engineer and put him on an engine you refuse to go and if they discharge you every man in Chicago will strike immediately for your re-instatement and that they Union will stand by that man. They said this would make it an individual and not a Union Strike. Opr was also cautioned to be very careful when talking about the matter to outside parties and never to day "they" will do this on "they" will do that but always say as an individual "I" will do so and so. This they claim will let them out of the clutches of the law. These parties also claimed that two L. Shore men came over and declared themselves, Once was a switchman formerly emplyed with the C.B.&Q. RR named Brown and he said he would stick to the strikers, the other was name was unknown. Pat Manning? stated that they could not get together before August but he supposed it would be best that the four organizations. Engineers, Switchmen, Firemen, and Brakemen (not including the conductors) should join hands and be amalgamated, that they would unclear strike
Completed

and prove to the railroads that they cannot discharge them or train will without good substancial reasons.
Opr was with an engineer and switchman both "Q" were from 2 to 4 P.M. They expressed themselves as wishing the thing over but did not know much about how matters stood at present as they had not attended the meeting for four on five days.
Report of Opr D.C. March 28" 1888
Today in Chicago Opr went to the place of meeting arriving there about ten minutes to ten O'clock. The meeting was called to order at 10.15 and lasted till 12.30 and then again from 3.00 to 5.00 O'Clock. They reported that they had not heard from the breakman and concluded that they were not going out. They have now gave to work on the L. Shore scabs. A L.Shore unclear switchman named Brown made a little speech. He said for himself that he would not handle a "Q" car and that there was 10 or 12 more L.Q. switchmen with him. He said he intended talking to some of the L.S. switchmen, but some he did not done talk to. A committee of two was appointed to wait an the L.S. switchman. Later this committee reported and both with these six L.S Switchmen
Completed

3.
but did not unclear the latter to the meeting. They wanted to know if they went out on this strike if they would be allowed to get into the switchmens' union after it was over. They were told that they could not be promised that, as the strikers would need to hold a meeting and vote on the subject before they could make any promises, but that they would promise to take him unclear off the black list on "scab list" and that they would be treated the same as thought they were members. Six men came from Columbus the night before last. They had four of them in the hall and the other two could not be found. These four switchmen pledged themselves that they were to go back to work in the South on wherever they may be such. They were asked where they would like to go and replied that they wanted to go North so were furnished with tranportation on the Milwaukee & St. Paul R. These four Columbus were stated that they did not know that there was a strike here. The strikers had a committee to work on the Fort Wayne engineers and they have pledged themselves that they would handle "Q" cars at all. If there is a track that has "Q" cars on there they will pull the cars behind the "Q" cars but will let the Burlington alone. The yard
Completed

4.
Masters. Jim Lyon. Patsey Conway and Joe Galway, said they would quit. A man named Kelly and another whose name Opr did not learn for certain but thinks it is unclear on r something like that (a man about 60 years of age and one of the oldest assistants yard-masters the road has got) such backward that if an assistant yard-master would go to them and explain why they should quit and unclear them as they should be treated, then they would probably quit. They had quite a discussion about the Pan Handle engineers, some of them claimed that the Pan Handle was not in favor of handling these cars, and other claimed that they would have them approach a committee to wait on them, but at this decided to wait a few days. In the hall the engineers occupy one side of it and the switchmen the other side and they have quite a wrangle during the meeting together. The switchmen claim that if they get their yard masters to quit that the engineers should get their foremen, at the Round House to quit also, they claimed that the Round House foremen were doing unclear damage than the yard-masters as the foremen were showing the Scabs what to do. Opr. met Johnson and took him to a saloon and talked to him for a half an hour but could get nothing out of him. The chairman before closing got

up and told the men not to loiter on the streets but go right home that they should not talk to any one and by no means to frequent saloons as they were being watched by Pinkerton men.

WIS
April 13th 88
I reported to Mr. unclear at 8 oclock am
After learning him I went to Union Depot the first man I met was Jos Whalon asst Depot Master talked with him a few minutes & asked him to a Raffel Ticket (for a Switchman who is going to raise some money on his furniture & I have some of the tickets to sell) He said who is it for. I said Jack unclear. He said unclear try so unclear broke as that & said yes give me one try will have to unclear the furniture before they win this strike. I then stayed around there about 30 min unclear did not see any one who was interested in the strike. Then got on an empty Passenger train & rode to Western Ave on the CM&S&P Ry saw Oliver Lockhart, Billie Sander while going up they are both switchmen for CM&S&P Ry & say they think
Completed

The Company will win. unclear has not much to say. But Lockhart is very bitter & says the Q will get the worst of it even if they do win the fight. Says he wished he was on Freight work so he could get a chance to help hold their transfer trains. But says the Boys will fix them without him. I first met in the yards up there Robert unclear who says he don't know any thing about the Strike only they told him one day to strike & in a couple of days they told him to go to work. Says he don't know why he struck & don't know why he went to work. I ask him from who he got his orders & he said he got no orders only the other Boys said so & added that if he ever struck again he would know why he struck. The rest could do as they thought best. Said the Q fellows had beat unclear out of good jobs & in his office the railroad
Completed

Company was done fooling with the men & would treat their Employees about right if they would only behave themselves. On the other had if they keep on striking every time they feel like it they will get shut down on by the Company & then they will be in a hell of a fix. Lockhart, Jandium? & Schorder came along & went to a saloon & had a drink & I went home.
After dinner I went to a Saloon on Halsted St. nearr 14th kept by Noonan Bros where the gang hang out. I then met 10 or 12 of them among the rest was Harrison the Yard Master who struck & scabed & struck again. He is a big unclear with the switchman now. I played cards with 3 of them for about 1 hour & a half. Billie Wells was the only one I knew. They were all talking about a C.B.&Q switchman who was hurt about unclear head sometime & went to
Completed

County Hospital they was very glad.
Then we went to the meeting & opened up with Brother Wooldredge in the Chair Reports of Committee say Case, Calkins, & Elliott are not working. Then there was Jay in the Comp. Engineer Paradise from Aurora was there & said every one was firm all along the line & success is sure. There was the same old talk from the Boys nothing of importance & meeting adjourned. I then walked to Noonan Bros saloon on Halsted & talked with everyone I could but they wouldn't talk strike very much. I stayed there until 7 oclock & came home. W.J.S
Completed

Today in Streator opr reports himself as getting well acquainted with the town and people and report that he makes inquires and gains his information in such a manner that no one seems to mistrust his mission. Opr reports that he knows nearly all the strikers by sight and some of them by name, but he find them still cautions in what they say Opr. heard bits of conversation among them yesterday in regard to the Dynamite Business and Opr heard one of them say that it was a mixed price of Business and that he believed the whole darn thing to be a fraud gotten up by the Pinkerton Agency to make the people think they have been doing something and get their names in the papers. Opr was about the Yards on his usual duty last night but every thing proved to be quiet and in order during the night, and he had nothing further to report.

Today in Streator Opr went about Town during the afternoon to the usual resorts of the Brotherhood Men. It being pay day on the Santa Fe. There were a number of the Santa Fe men out having a Time. Friday July 27th/88
Today in Streator at 8.00 P.M. Opr left the Hotel and started for the Q yard, but a heavy rain storm came up before he reached the yard, so he did not get there until after the passenger train came from the north, however he found every thing alright with the exception of two switch lights which were probably blow out by the wind as they have been on stormy nights before. Opr. remained in the vicinity of the yard until 2.30 A.M. when every thing being quiet he returned to the Hotel.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkerton's Nat'l. Det. Agency
By W.A. Pinkerton
Genl. Supt. W. Div.
a.r.

Dear Sir:
Following you will please find reports of Opr. J.H.S for July 26th & 27th 
Thursday July 26th 1888
Today in Streator, Opr went about town & to the resorts of the Brotherhood men, but could find only one of the strikers, and learned nothing of importance. He went to the Q yards at 7.40 P.M. a terrific storm passed over just previous to that time. Opr. found that the switch lights had been blown out, but otherwise every thing was alright, and nothing of interest took place up to 2.05 A.M. when Opr. returned to the Hotel.
Friday July 27th 1888
Today in Streator Opr. went about town as usual but learned nothing new. He went to the Q yards at 7.50 P.M. and every thing alright and nothing unusual occurred during the night. Every thing being quiet, he
Completed

returned to the Hotel at 2.30 AM.
Yours Respectfully

Chicago Aug 21th 1888
N. B. Stone Esq
Genl Mgr. C.B. & Q R.R.
City
Dear Sir:
Following you will please find reports of Opr R.Y. for Aug 17 & 18
Friday, Aug 17th/88
Today is Straton Opr., left his room at 10 A.M. and took in several saloons where strikers hang out, and saw a few of the strikers but did not hear them say any thing about the strike. At about 7 P.M. there were several strikers in front of Kennedy's saloon 74 Main St. listening to a band playing they all went to a Minstrel show in the Opera House. At 7.45 P.M. Opr. went up into the "Q" yards and found the switches alright with the exception of two which had no lights on them. He made several rounds around the Round House during the evening, but saw nothing to indicate that the men had been there. There were several persons passed through the yards on their way home from the show, but none of them molested any thing in the yards. He saw no
Completed

one tamper with the switches on cars during the night and all bring quiet he discontinued at 3 AM.
Saturday Aug 18th/88
Today in Straton at 1130 AM Opr made his usual rounds to the different saloons and saw several of the strikers but none of them talked about the strike. He also saw several of the men who took the strikers places, the strikers said nothing to them, but would point them out to each other. At 7.30 P.M. he went up to the "Q" yards and found the switches alright, except two which were with out lights. At about 8.15 P.M. there were three or four switchmen standing a little south of C. & A. R.R. crossing on the "Q" track, and two girls or young ladys passed along the street and one of the switchmen said "hello Jennie," to one of them, but she did not answer him, & he ^ then began making insulting remards to the m and laughed and yelled after them. A man passing at the time said it was a d--- shame to hear to put up with that from a d--- "scab" the same switchmen then signaled for a switch engine to come ahead with some cars, and as the engine passed he swore at the engineer and told
Completed

him to hurry up, and the engineer told him to go to h---, the switchman followed the engine towards the Depot calling the engineer all the names he could think of and swearing and ^ calling to the engineer to get off of his engine. Opr. could not get off of his engine. Opr. could not get the number of the engine, the switchman talked like an english man Opr. went around the round house seeral times during the night but saw no sign of the men having been there, he did not see any one molest the switches or cars during the night and as every thing was quiet he discontinued at 3.30 A.M.
Yours Respectfully
Pinkerton's Natl. Det Agcy
by W. A. Pinkerton
Gen'l. Supt. West. Div

Chicago Aug 23rd 1888
H.B. Stone Esq
Genl. Mgr. C.B.&Q. R.R.
City
Dear Sir,
Following you will please find reports of Opr. R.G. for Aug 21st & 22nd
Tuesday, Aug 21st 1888
Today in Streator Opr. left his room at 11.45 AM and went around to different saloons where the strikers generally hang out and at Kennedys saloon #74 Main St. he was told by one of the bartenders that a young fellow, a breakman on the "Q" saw him (Opr) in the saloon on the night before and said he had seen him (Opr) in Aurora last spring, and that he (Opr) boarded at Heck's Hotel and that he though Opr. was Pinkerton man. The bartender said they did not believe him and for Opr. to be careful of the strikers. Opr. denied ever being at Heck's and said he was going away in a day or two. Opr. saw Mr. McDowd in the evening and told him about what he had heard & OPr. told Mr. McD. that he would have to leave town.
Completed

Mr. McD. did not wish to have Opr. leave until another man came and Opr. told him he would send a letter and it would arrive at the Agency in the morning, and he would leave in the afternoon of the same day & Mr. McD thought that would be alright, as it would give another man a chance to get there. Opr. went into the Yards at 7.45 P.M. and found the switches alright except tow which were without lights. Every thing being quiet he discontinued at 4 A.M.
Wednesday, Aug 22nd 1888
Today in Streator at 11 A.M. Opr left his room and made arrangements to leave town and at 2.30 P.M. Mr. McDowd came to Opr. and gave him a telegram telling Opr. to take the first train for Chicago. Opr. left Streator on the 3 P.M. train and arrived in Chicago at 6.50 and reported to the Agency.
Your Respectfully
Pinkerton's Nat'l Det. Agcy
by W.A. Pinkerton
Genl Supt West Div
A.R.
Completed

Dear Sir:
Following you will please find report of Opr. R.G.
Sunday, Aug 19th 1888
Today in Streator according to instructions Opr. left his room at 12 noon and remained around that streets for a couple of hours and then went to a picnic on Peanut Hill where there were several strikers and quiet a number of R.R. men, they were all very orderly, and Opr. heard no one talk of the strike. Opr. left at 6 P.M. and got his supper & at 7.45 P.M. proceeded to the Q yards & found the switches alright except two which were with out lights, he made his usual trips around the round house but saw on indications that the men had been there. Every thing was quiet during the night and no one tampered with the cars or switches. Opr. discontinued at 3 A.M.
Your Respectfully
Pinkerton's Nat Det. Agency
by W.A. Pinkerton
Genl. Supt. West Div.

Chicago Illinois
August 30th 1888.
H.B. Stone Esq.
Genl. Manager C.B.&Q. R.R.
City
Dear Sir
Following find report of Opr. P.L.G. sated at Streator Ills. Tuesday August 28th 1888.
Operative reports that about 11 A.M. of Aug 28th he went to Hobans? Saloon. had the "Times" with him he called the attention to the article showing the Mackay Strike settled Hoban? replied, "Old Stone gave the Brotherhood such a drubbing that he guessed they got scared at Mackay's talk" One of the 5 men in the saloon said, "well while Old Stone is on top he has no Victory yet." Opr. lost 1 game of dice while talking and at 12.15 PM he met Supt Alexander for a few moments and afterwards he met McDaniels who told Opr. that Alexander went through the Yard that had a target on and to lock the Switch at the Public Street Crossing. about 3 pm Opr went to Kennedys Saloon and threw dice for Cigars with the Bartender and his man in conversation shows his bitterness against the Co. or its employees by saying he would not sell a drink to a scab if he knew it.
Completed

2.
About 7 p.m. Opr Saw Supt Rice who asked Opr how long he had been at Streator and if Opr. was the only Opr there. Opr told him that so far as he (Opr) knew he was the only one there! Mr. Rice also asked Opr about the Yard and Opr told him that the unlighted switches were the ones that were tampered with and also called his attention to the larger of the switch at the Public Crossing - Mr. Rice asked if Lamps had not been ordered  for the switches yet, Opr told Mr. Rice that the understanding from Mr. McDaniels was that Mr. Alexander had ordered these.
At 8 oclock p.m. Opr went to a point where he could cover both switches that had been tampered with and remained there until 10.45 p.m. then went Down Town to Lunch. returned and remained watching both switches until 4 a.m. then concluding that all would be safe. Opr discontinued.
Yours Truly.
Pinkertons Nat'l Det Agcy
per Wm A Pinkerton. Genl Supt
West Div

Saturday Aug 26th 1888
Today in Streator At 11 A.M. the Opr went to Lees restaurant got a cigar and in a general conversation would judge him to be strongly in favor of the strikers. At about 4 P.M. the Opr went to the drugstore and unclear stand and while watching the arrival of papers had a general conversation about Lowasucys? Finley and others who were there in 1877. He was there said "Oh Yes you know there is always an unclear in a winning tower that favors strikers and strikers but I think the Ry Co is right in the stand they have taken, that is to stick to the men leave stuck to them. At 8 p.m. the Opr took a unclear to watch the two unlighted switches supposed to have been tampered with, he remained there

Chicago Illinois Aug 9 1888
H.B. Stone Esq.
Genl Mangr W.B. & A. R.R.
Dear Sir.
Following find report of Opr R.G. dated at Sheator Ills. Monday Aug 6th 1888
Opr Reports that pursuant to instructions from Mr Paris he went out to the Race Tracks with some young men among whom 3 were strikers nothing was said about the strike they were all nice fellows apparently. at 7pm. Opr went to Mr Paris' room and was introduced to Mr McDaniel assistant Round house ? at Aurora who is to take Mr Paris place for a short time Opr then went up into the ? Yard and found that 2 switches had no lamps on them and found a 3d switch with a lamp on but the light was nearly out Opr thinks whoever has charge of those lamps is negligent and at 10pm Opr informed Mr Paris of the lamps by sending him a note and when Opr returned to the switches and went up to them he saw a man standing a short distance away. The man saw Opr and walked away up to the switch when Opr left it. Opr says if such occurrences should happen often he cannot keep under cover long. Opr saw no suspicious persons around during the night and no one disturbed the switches.
Yours Truly
Pinkertons Nat Det Agcy
per W A Pinkerton Genl Supt West Div

Chicago
Dear Sir
Following find report of Opr R.G. dated at Streator Ills. Thursday August 9th 1888
Opreatin reports that today in Streator acting under instructions of Mr McDaniel Master Mechanic. Opr remained around town during the day and saw several strikers. all very gentlemanly and quiet. They all went to the Races this afternoon. Opr saw Mr McDaniel who told Opr there were no lamps for the switches before mentioned. They have lamps on the switches near the round house nearly 2 blocks away from the main tracks, and when no switching is done and only an occasional engine passes, going to and from the Round House Opr went up into the yard soon as it was dark, saw no one round and the switches remained undisturbed and at 2a.m. Opr discontinued.
August 10th 1888
Operation further reports that nearly all business was suspended today at noon and everybody went to the races. Opr went also with Mr. Kennedy the saloon keeper at 74 Main St and several strikers and prize fighters they were all very good natured at the races. Opr returned
Completed

2
to town at 7p.m. received a note from Mr McD. who said he was sick and had gone home. Opr at dark went as usual to the yards saw two men sitting on some ties. they left when the 8:30p.m. train came in Opr saw no other strangers in the yards during the night and no one tampered with the RR property or switches.
There were no lamps as before reported on the two switches. at 2a.m. Opr discontinued
Saturday August 11th 1888
Opr further reports that he remained around Kennedy's saloon. No 74 Main St. most of the day as there were quite a no of strikers there but they were very orderly talked  little of the strike. Mr McD. returned here this 7:45am. Opr found one of the lights out on one of the switches. Opr informed Mr McD who said he would see that lamps were on all the switches and he told Opr to watch the men around the round house some during the night as he thought they have been around there sometimes
Opr saw now suspicious persons around the yards tonight and the switches were unmolested. at 2:30am everything being quiet Opr discontinued.
Monday August 13th 1888.
Operative further reports that he remained around Saloon at 74 Main St. during the day saw a few of the strikers.
